item.title: Ticket #3251 (wordpress.org/search each page displays same results and sometimes no ...) reopened
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
masquerade: I appreciate your perspective and possibly another solution is better, but I don't see it as an immediate issue considering the few bugs reported against this component.

Currently there is a component of WordPress.org, so this bug is valid. Seeing how there is not currently a better place for WP infrastructure bugs, this bug is valid.

item.title: Ticket #3251 (wordpress.org/search each page displays same results and sometimes no ...) closed
item.dc:creator: masquerade
item.description:
invalid:

Can we not file things that are not directly related to the code, especially issues that nobody in the community but Matt or someone else with server admin status, as a bug here? I'd say bring it up on one of the lists or e-mail Matt directly, but seeing as this has nothing to do with the WordPress code, it really doesn't belong here.

item.title: Ticket #3238 (Bug Fix in wpautop for Dangling Paragraph Tag in Wordpress Comments) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description: Ghidra99, Can you add your fix as a patch? It is so much easier to read. Also, please consider commenting whether the same issue exists on trunk and a patch for it.

item.title: Ticket #3251 (wordpress.org/search each page displays same results and sometimes no ...) updated
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description: Severity changed

item.title: Ticket #3251 (wordpress.org/search each page displays same results and sometimes no ...) created
item.dc:creator: foolswisdom
item.description:
wordpress.org/search each page displays same results and sometimes no results are found

EXAMPLE:

​http://wordpress.org/search/css?documentation=1&p=2

results are identical to

​http://wordpress.org/search/css?documentation=1&p=200

Sometimes a search will report no results.

ADDITIONAL DETAILS

I played around with the code for a while and the code looks good. My guess is that it is a "proxy" issue or cache.

item.title: Ticket #3248 (Need way to replace WPDB error message) updated
item.dc:creator: Nazgul
item.description:
You can achieve that by setting $wpdb to some value before including wp-db.php and setting it to your derived class afterwards.

wp-db.php only instantiates $wpdb if it's not already set.

Not the most elegant way, but it works.

item.title: wp_redirect.diff attached to Ticket #3250
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Patch for trunk

item.title: Ticket #3250 (Add filter (with cancel ability) to wp_redirect() function) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Patch adds a filter to the $location in wp_redirect. If $location is false after the filter, the function aborts, which means that a filter would be able to cancel a given redirect.

While writing a plugin today, I happened upon a circumstance where this would have been very useful.

item.title: Ticket #3249 (Nothing in wp-db.php is translatable) updated
item.dc:creator: Sewar
item.description:
Keywords changed

Because wp-db.php loaded before locales, it's second file loaded in wp-settings.php ASC and locale.php is second DESC!

item.title: Ticket #3248 (Need way to replace WPDB error message) reopened
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Surely this should be as easy as basing your class on wpdb and overriding the contructor.

We may need to change the way in which wpdb is instantiated to make this easier. As at present you can't include the real wpdb and extend it without $wpdb being created as normal.

item.title: Ticket #3248 (Need way to replace WPDB error message) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
We need some way to easily replace the error message(s) for unable to connect to the database in wp-db.php. A hook wouldn't work 'cause no plugins would run before then (since we don't know what's activated), so perhaps something in the same way that advanced-cache.php works would be in order.

Thoughts?

item.description: Some helper functions for themes and images

item.dc:creator: matt
item.description: Allow themes in subdirectories.

item.title: Ticket #3247 (Planet feed on Dashboard obscures titles and source sites) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Honestly, I'm not thrilled with the current "uniform boxes" look of that part of the dashboard... but were that to stay, I'd say that it'd be best to figure out (conservatively) how many characters can find on a line, and if it exceeds, chop the last 4 and add " ..."

We could have some more breathing room if the font size were smaller.

Finally, it'd at least look a little bit better if the height of the title/site were such that a certain number of lines would show, exactly (no mid-line chop). It looks to be a few pixels off from that, right now.

You can use ​Secure Admin which used in WordPress.Com, see: ​http://wordpress.com/blog/2006/03/08/secure-blogging/.

item.title: Ticket #2864 (Magpie falling behind feed developments) reopened
item.dc:creator: matt
item.description:
This is entirely unacceptable.

We just broke everything that uses our RSS libraries in the world. If simplepie can't maintain the same external functions, like fetch_rss and the old object structure, then we shouldn't use it. Nothing in WP should have changed except the library.

Also, the dashboard is now loading entire posts rather than descriptions.

item.title: menu-header.php.diff attached to Ticket #3246
item.dc:creator: bmontgom
item.description: patch for menu-headers.php

item.title: Ticket #3246 (make menu items in menu-headers.php relative) created
item.dc:creator: bmontgom
item.description: The URIs for the menu items in menu-headers.php are not relative URIs. These are the only URIs on the page that are not this way. I've been working on a plugin to allow for the login, register, and admin functions to be done using SSL. It is working, but I had to modify menu-headers.php to make the menu item URIs relative in order to get everything correct. A patch for my changes is attached.
